Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Functional Characterization of Diphospho- and Triphospho-Inositol Phosphates in Plants

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
A novel set of compounds that consist of inositol linked to multiple phosphate groups play critical roles in the metabolism and stress responses of many different types of organisms. Preliminary data reveal that these compounds (here called PPx-InsPs) are also present in plants, but very little is known about their synthesis and potential functions. This research will test the hypotheses that PPx-InsPs act as sensors of metabolism and stress in plants, and are critical for basic metabolism during seed development and growth. To test these hypotheses this project will 1) identify and accurately measure the concentrations of PPx-InsPs in plant tissues; 2) identify and characterize plant enzymes that regulate the levels of PPx-InsPs; and 3) characterize the stress responses of plants that contain genetic alterations in the enzymes that regulate the levels of PPx-InsPs. The long-term goals of this collaborative project are to understand how these unique PPx-InsP molecules are regulated in plants and how they help control metabolism, plant stress and phosphate sensing.

Broader Impacts. This project will support the education and training of three graduate students, one postdoctoral fellow, and a number of undergraduate students. The diverse interests and backgrounds of the three collaborators (who serve at universities and a USDA research laboratory) offer unique opportunities for synergistic interactions. An exchange of investigators (including postdoctoral fellows and students) will occur between laboratories, providing exposure to different research programs and the experience of working in a large research team. Members of this team will participate in two programs designed to foster the development of young scientists. In one program (Partnership for Research and Education in Plants, or PREP) the research will be integrated into the high school science curriculum by donating plant strains from this project and by working with PREP staff and high school students in inquiry-based learning projects. In the second program, the research team will develop and participate in hands-on activities with over 400 elementary school students in the Kid's Tech University which is held at Virginia Tech each year.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This work is focused on understanding the role of novel inositol pyrophosphate signaling molecules (PPx-InsPs) in plants.  PPx-InsPs are inositol phosphates containing high energy pyrophosphate bonds at one or more positions on the inositol ring.  When our collaborative research started, these molecules were emerging as critical players in the integration of cellular metabolism and stress signaling in animals; however little was known about their function in plants. Inositol pyrophosphates are derived from inositol hexakisphosphate, which (when complexed with cations) is known as phytate.  High phytate levels in plant seeds, along with over application of phosphate fertilizer, present environmental challenges by contributing to the phosphate run off and pollution of fresh water. Thus understanding how plants use molecules such as the PPx-InsPs is critical for addressing phosphate relations in plants.

We first developed analytical methods to detect and quantify PPx-InsPs in various plant tissues. We found that all plants and tissues examined accumulate very small levels of PPx-InsPs. We also identified and characterized the plant enzymes responsible for synthesis of PPx-InsPs, and developed genetic mutants that can be used to address how these genes function in plants. We determined that a genetic mutant altered in seed phytate contains elevated PPs-InsP levels. Most significantly, we discovered changes in the pathway under low energy and limiting phosphate conditions supporting the regulatory role of PPx-InsPs in the low energy and low phosphate signaling networks in plants.  The energy and nutrient status is critical for regulating developmental transitions such as flowering in plants as well as being a key determinant of plant biomass; therefore this understanding has broad applications for plant growth and crop improvement. 

This work has resulted in primary research publications and has been presented at several national and international conferences.  This project has supported and trained students at all levels of education from high school to undergraduate and graduate, as well as post graduate researchers. In addition, our outreach activities have contributed to Science Technology Engineering and Math (STEM) education in both Virginia and North Carolina. These efforts engaged over 1000 elementary school students in hands-on activities extracting plant DNA, and 400+ high school students who used genetic mutants from this project in their own, authentic inquiry. Engagement with biology, chemistry, art and photography high school teachers and students was facilitated by establishing a partnership with an experimental STEM lab contained within a Virginia high school.
